messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Explicit two-sided unique-neighbor expanders

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the problem of constructing explicit sparse graphs that exhibit strong vertex expansion. Our main result is the first two-sided construction of imbalanced unique-neighbor expanders, meaning bipartite graphs where small sets contained in both the left and right bipartitions exhibit unique-neighbor expansion, along with algebraic properties relevant to constructing quantum codes. Our constructions are obtained from instantiations of the tripartite line product of a large tripartite spectral expander and a sufficiently good constant-sized unique-neighbor expander, a new graph product we defined that generalizes the line product in the work of Alon and Capalbo [AC02] and the routed product in the work of Asherov and Dinur [AD23]. To analyze the vertex expansion of graphs arising from the tripartite line product, we develop a sharp characterization of subgraphs that can arise in bipartite spectral expanders, generalizing results of Kahale [Kah95], which may be of independent interest. By picking appropriate graphs to apply our product to, we give a strongly explicit construction of an infinite family of (d1,d2)subscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2(d_{1},d_{2})-biregular graphs (Gn)n⩾1subscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑛1(G_{n})_{n\geqslant 1} (for large enough d1subscript𝑑1d_{1} and d2subscript𝑑2d_{2}) where all sets S𝑆S with fewer than a small constant fraction of vertices have Ω​(d1⋅|S|)Ω⋅subscript𝑑1𝑆\Omega(d_{1}\cdot|S|) unique-neighbors (assuming d1⩽d2subscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2d_{1}\leqslant d_{2}). Additionally, we can also guarantee that subsets of vertices of size up to exp⁡(Ω​(log⁡|V​(Gn)|))Ω𝑉subscript𝐺𝑛\exp(\Omega(\sqrt{\log|V(G_{n})|})) expand losslessly.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "NLTS Hamiltonians from good quantum codes",
        "Explicit construction of linear sized tolerant networks",
        "Explicit unique-neighbor expanders",
        "Bipartite unique-neighbour expanders via Ramanujan graphs",
        "The Moore bound for irregular graphs",
        "On-Line Algorithms for Path Selection in a Nonblocking Network",
        "The Ihara-Selberg zeta function of a tree lattice",
        "Symmetric unique neighbor expanders and good LDPC codes",
        "Explicit construction of Ramanujan bigraphs",
        "Combining geometry and combinatorics: A unified approach to sparse signal recovery",
        "Tensor products of weakly smooth codes are robust",
        "HDX condensers",
        "Randomness conductors and constant-degree lossless expanders",
        "Locally Testable Codes with constant rate, distance, and locality",
        "Explicit sos lower bounds from high-dimensional expanders",
        "Embedding the Erdős–Rényi hypergraph into the random regular hypergraph and Hamiltonicity",
        "Good Quantum LDPC Codes with Linear Time Decoders",
        "Robust local testability of tensor products of LDPC codes",
        "Introduction to random graphs",
        "How well do local algorithms solve semidefinite programs?",
        "Almost Euclidean subspaces of ℓ1Nsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑁\\ell_{1}^{N} via expander codes",
        "ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\\ell_{p}-Spread and Restricted Isometry Properties of Sparse Random Matrices",
        "New Explicit Constant-Degree Lossless Expanders",
        "An efficient decoder for a linear distance quantum LDPC code",
        "Linear lower bound on degrees of Positivstellensatz calculus proofs for the parity",
        "Unbalanced expanders and randomness extractors from Parvaresh–Vardy codes",
        "Zeta functions of finite graphs and representations of p-adic groups",
        "A simple and sharper proof of the hypergraph Moore bound",
        "Explicit lower bounds against ω𝜔\\omega (n)-rounds of sum-of-squares",
        "Expander graphs and their applications",
        "Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables",
        "On discrete subgroups of the two by two projective linear group over p-adic fields",
        "Eigenvalues and expansion of regular graphs",
        "Deterministic construction of a high dimensional ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\\ell_{p} section in ℓ1nsuperscriptsubscriptℓ1𝑛\\ell_{1}^{n} for any p<2𝑝2p<2",
        "Fault-tolerant quantum computation by anyons",
        "Combinatorics via closed orbits: number theoretic Ramanujan graphs are not unique neighbor expanders",
        "Simple constructions of unique neighbor expanders from error-correcting codes",
        "Good quantum LDPC codes with linear time decoder from lossless expanders",
        "Ramanujan graphs",
        "Quantum tanner codes",
        "Efficient decoding up to a constant fraction of the code length for asymptotically good quantum codes",
        "Explicit group-theoretical constructions of combinatorial schemes and their application to the design of expanders and concentrators",
        "High-Girth Near-Ramanujan Graphs with Lossy Vertex Expansion",
        "Explicit near-Ramanujan graphs of every degree",
        "Existence and explicit constructions of q+ 1 regular Ramanujan graphs for every prime power q",
        "Explicit near-fully X-Ramanujan graphs",
        "Asymptotically good quantum and locally testable classical LDPC codes",
        "Entropy waves, the zig-zag graph product, and new constant-degree expanders and extractors",
        "Linear level lasserre lower bounds for certain k-csps",
        "Expander codes",
        "A recursive approach to low complexity codes",
        "Lossless condensers, unbalanced expanders, and extractors"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Explicit two-sided unique-neighbor expanders, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
